metadata.title: Sever’s Disease
anatomical location body part affected: The Achilles tendon inserts into the posterior calcaneus where a cartilaginous growth plate exists in children and adolescents(2)
description: Sever’s disease, or calcanealapophysitis, is a repetitive traction injury in children at the growth center of the calcaneus. Occurring during a period of rapid growth, excessive traction from the Achilles tendon can cause micro avulsions where it inserts onto the calcaneus(2)

Sever’s disease is the most common cause of heel pain in active adolescents aged 9–12 years old, typically occurring during a period of rapid growth. Risk factors include year-round  sports participation, commonly involving sports that require repetitive running or jumping, poorly fitting footwear, and poor training mechanics. It occurs more frequently in males, occurring at a median age of 12 for males and 11 for females(2)

ICD-10 codes.M92.6: juvenile osteochondrosis of tarsus (specifically the calcaneus) (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Localized dull ache and tenderness in the posterior heel area(1,7)
Condition has worsened over a few weeks and interferes with playing sports(7)
Symptoms are bilateral in up to 60% of cases(2)
The child is in or has gone through a growth spurt(4) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Must rule out any form of fracture involving the calcaneus

causes: The main cause of Sever’s disease symptoms usually cited is increased tension of theAchilles tendon on the unossified or incompletely ossified calcanealapophysis(2)
Poor heel cord flexibility or weak dorsiflexor muscles can also be a contributing causeof increased tension at the Achilles tendon insertion(2)
pathogenesis: Sever(3) originally attributed symptoms to apophysitis of the calcaneus(1,6)

The pathogenesis is believed to be similar to that of Osgood-Schlatter  syndrome (see  Clinical Review ... Osgood-SchlatterSyndrome  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708419)–As a child grows, bones go through different stages of development. The growth center initially is cartilaginous(cartilaginous stage). The growth center then enters the apophyseal stage, during which the secondary ossification center(apophysis) appears. The initial unity of both ends of the growth center marks the epiphyseal stage. Lastly, when thegrowth plates fuse, the bony stage begins–Children are most susceptible to Sever’s disease when their bones are in the apophyseal stage. The apophysis is unableto withstand tensile forces. When presented with strong, repetitive muscle contractions, microavulsion occurs at theimmature area. The separation results in symptoms typical of any form of apophysitis
risk factors: The main risk factor is sports participation before skeletal maturity. Sports that involve repetitive running and jumping(e.g., basketball, soccer, track, cross-country,  and gymnastics) appear to increase risk(2)
Primarily seen between ages 8 and 15 years(6)

overall contraindications precautions: See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Must rule out any form of fracture involving the calcaneus

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Is the patient at risk due to type of physical activity and age? Is the patient currently in a growth spurt? Was pain onset gradual or sudden?

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management. How has the lower leg responded to treatments?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed, if any; are they being taken? NSAIDs and steroid injections might be given
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnosis usually is based on the history and clinical findings. Imaging is typically not necessary(2)
Might reveal reduced density or atrophy of the calcaneal epiphysis

Based on a study in China, X-rays  of children with Sever’s disease show an increase in the density of the calcaneal epiphysis and a radiolucent line, which may also be observed in healthy children. Therefore, it may be difficult to
diagnose Sever’s disease by Xray alone; however, X-rays  are useful to rule out other conditions such as fractures, osteomyelitis, and calcaneal tumors(1)
MRI  useful for identifying soft tissue edema, bone marrow edema, synovial thickening, and joint effusion(1)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Does weight-bearing aggravate the pain? Symptoms frequently are worse with prolonged walking. The pain increases when climbing stairs or running and interferes with playing sports. Toe walking might help reduce pain
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Pain is located in the posterior heel area. Are both feet affected? Note that bilateral symptoms are not uncommon(2)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Pain usually is described as a dull ache and tenderness in the posterior heel area
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). The Oucher scale can used in children
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes___ No___ -If Yes, describe _______________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Any history of heel pain or foot injuries?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other health conditions, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in a sport that involves running? How has this injury affected the patient’s life? The main risk factor is sports participation before skeletal maturity. Sports that involve running and jumping appear to increase risk
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Is the patient dependent on ambulatory assistance?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Assess for leg-length  discrepancy. If weight is suspected to be a contributing factor, measure height and weight in order to calculate BMI
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance typically is not affected unless pain is severe enough, resulting in difficulty with weight-bearing  on the involved lower extremity
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Pedal pulses should be normalNerves typically are not affected
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Perform thorough gait assessment, as patients often compensate for heel pain by toe walkingAccessory motion of talocrural or subtalar joints should not be affected by this condition
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess major lower extremity muscle groups for normal age-related  strength. Weakness is commonly found in the affected ankle dorsiflexors –Assess for provocation of pain with resisted plantar flexion at 90° of ankle dorsiflexionAssess whether the patient has met developmental milestones
observation inspection palpation includi: Note presence of any muscle atrophy. Any significant swelling or ecchymosis is indicative of more serious trauma than usually seen in Sever’s disease
There usually is no swelling, skin changes, or erythema. Inspect posterior calcaneus for deformities. Check for poor-fitting  or worn-out  shoes
There should be no tenderness on the plantar surface, around the ankle joint or the proximal Achilles tendon. Assess pain/ tenderness (V AS) at the calcaneus attachment of Achilles tendon
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess knee, leg, and foot alignment for postural defects that might require orthotic correction
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Measure ROM at the ankle and assess flexibility, as calf muscle (gastrocnemius-soleus  complex) is often tight
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosisManually compress the lateral and medial sides of the posterior calcaneus. A positive test is if sharp pain or tenderness is provoked(2)

contraindications precautions: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide and does not replace orders from a physician or the specific protocols of the treatment clinic
Cryotherapy contraindications(5) -Raynaud’s syndrome -Cryoglobulinemia -Cold urticaria -Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria -Impaired circulation -Over area of nerve regrowth
Cryotherapy precautions(5) -Hypertension -Hypersensitivity to cold -Over an acute wound -Over superficial nerves

Thermotherapy contraindications(5) -Decreased circulation -Decreased sensation -Acute/subacute traumatic and inflammatory conditions -Skin infections -Impaired cognition or language barrier -Malignancy -Liniments -Presence of or tendency for hemorrhage or edema -Heat rubs

Therapeutic ultrasound  contraindications; do not use:(5) -Over the region of a cardiac pacemaker -Over the pelvis, abdominal, and lumbar regions during pregnancy -Over the eyes or testes -In an area with infection or bleeding -If a tumor or malignancy is present in the area -In the area of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or thrombophlebitis -Over the heart, stellate, or cervical ganglia  -Over epiphyseal plates

Therapeutic ultrasound precautions(5) -Sensory deficits -Ineffective communication skills in a patient (e.g., impaired cognition, language barrier) -Circulatory impairments -Plastic or metal implants -Peripheral vascular disease -Note: Always decrease ultrasound intensity if the patient complains of discomfort
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment in their assessment and treatment decisions

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Physical exam findings that confirm Sever’s syndrome. Physical therapy is indicated to restore strength and flexibility of tissues around the ankle. Guidance needed for planning safe return to vigorous activities/ sport
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Calcaneal stress fracture Heel infection (calcaneal osteomyelitis) Plantar fasciitis Neoplasm (e.g., osteoid osteoma, calcaneal bone cyst) Tarsal coalition Achilles tendinopathy Calf muscle strain Ankle sprain Rheumatoid arthritis Posterior shin splints Referral from lumbar spine nerve root and/or peripheral nerve injury
prognosis: It may take a few months for symptoms to resolve. No serious long-term complications have been associated with Sever’s disease. The condition may return again and resolve as the child is growing; however, children will eventually outgrow the condition as their growth plates harden(4)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedist as indicated Generally, immobilization is discouraged. However, orthopedic consultation may be indicated for a trial of immobilization (e.g., casting, CAM boot)(2) Orthotist/podiatrist for orthotics Psychologist/psychiatrist for concerns about depression
other considerations: Steroid injection and/or surgery might need to be considered in recalcitrant cases
treatment summary: Treatment has traditionally focused on reducing pain and swelling.Typical treatment components include(3) –activity modification or limitation –stretching of the gastrocnemius-soleus  complex –NSAIDs –ice application –orthotic heel lift –immobilization— if the condition has not improved with conservative treatment and rest(4)

Authors of a randomized controlled study in Turkey comparingkinesiology taping to sham taping concludedthat kinesiology taping can be effectively used for restoring ankle function in children with calcaneal apophysitis(8) –The authors noted that the role of kinesiology taping in pain improvement is limited; however, they also stated that it was an effective modality to reduce pain compared to placebo in children with calcaneal apophysitis –Twenty-two  participants were included in this study. Participants were male junior football players between 8 and 16 years old in whom calcaneal apophysitis had been diagnosed via radiographic and clinical examination ›. Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Pain during daily activities and/or sport with tenderness at the Achilles tendon insertionAbsent or decreased exertional painPhysical agents/ mechanical modalities _ Frequent icing for pain in heel area. Evidence is not available on whether electrophysical modalities can help manage Sever’s disease symptoms. Clinicians should avoid use of ultrasound over growth plates(5) _ _

maintenance or prevention: Defer the athlete’s return to competition and modify training if pain persists on sports-specific  exertion. Preventive management on return to sport should include instruction for immediate relative rest if symptoms return
